channel.title: Ruby on Memo Tut
channel.description: Recent content in Ruby on Memo Tut

item.title: [Python] AtCoder ABC 107 B string manipulation solved with Ruby, Perl, Java and Python
item.description: #Introduction AtCoder Problems is used to solve past problems. Thank you, AtCoder and AtCoder Problems. This time AtCoder Beginner Contest 107 B-Grid Compression Difficulty: 434 This theme, string operation Ruby h, w = gets.split.map(&:to_i) a = [] h.times do |i| s = gets.chomp a.push(s) if s.index('#') end (w-1).downto(0) do |i| if a.all?{|x| x[i] =='.'} a.each do |x| x[i] ='' end end end puts a a.push(s) if s.count('.') != w a.

item.title: [Python] Solving AtCoder ARC 086 C hashes in Ruby, Perl, Java and Python
item.description: #Introduction AtCoder Problems is used to solve past problems. Thank you, AtCoder and AtCoder Problems. This time AtCoder Regular Contest 086 C-Not so Diverse Difficulty: 431 This theme, hash sorting Ruby Speaking of duplicate lists, it’s a hash. n, k = gets.split.map(&:to_i) a = gets.split.map(&:to_i) h = Hash.new(0) a.each do |x| h[x] += 1 end puts n-h.values.sort.reverse[0, k].inject(:+) h.sort_by{|key, v| -v}.each do |key, v| puts n-h.values.sort.reverse[0, k].inject(:+) ~~Ruby doesn’t have a destructive sort of hashes, but it seems to have few uses.

item.title: [Python] AtCoder AGC 033 A breadth-first search solved with Ruby, Perl, Java and Python
item.description: #Introduction AtCoder Problems is used to solve past problems. Thank you, AtCoder and AtCoder Problems. This time AtCoder Grand Contest 033 A-Darker and Darker Difficulty: 1245 This theme, breadth-first search Ruby This is an advanced version of AtCoder Typical Contest 002 A-breadth-first search that I solved earlier. In particular, there are severe conditions such as execution time limit: 1 sec. h, w = gets.split.map(&:to_i) cm = Array.new(h + 2){Array.new(w + 2, 0)} que = [] 1.

item.title: [Python] AtCoder ABC 131 D Array Sorting Solved with Ruby, Perl, Java and Python
item.description: #Introduction AtCoder Problems is used to solve past problems. Thank you, AtCoder and AtCoder Problems. This time AtCoder Beginner Contest 131 D-Megalomania Difficulty: 594 This theme, array sort Ruby It’s an array sort, so I think it’s easy to implement. ~~ I chose a lighter problem because it is the first Python. ~~ n = gets.to_i a = Array.new(n){gets.split.map(&:to_i)} a.sort_by!{|x| x[1]} ans = 0 n.times do |i| ans += a[i][0] if ans >a[i][1] puts "No" exit end end puts "Yes" a.

item.title: [Python] 3 months after graduating from programming school
item.description: In October 2019, I attended a certain programming school where I often see advertisements on youtube, and since November I have been in my current position as a machine learning engineer and data scientist. Three months after graduating, I would like to write about what I learned from the school, what was useful, and what is difficult now. Biography April 2015 Served as a research and development position for a food company for 4 years July 2019 Start of programming school learning October 2019, graduated from programming school November 2019 Job change as a machine learning engineer and data scientist

item.title: [Python] Script language KINX (Introduction)
item.description: #Introduction I wrote Things like this before, but as an artisan, I was tempted to make my own tools. https://github.com/Kray-G/kinx Looks like JavaScript, feels like Ruby, and it is the script language fitting in C programmers. Well, even if you say no, it’s something you can find somewhere (I won’t say it here), but I’m lonely even if I’m self-satisfied, so let’s leave a footstep for commentary.

item.title: [Python] Why VBScript True is -1
item.description: According to the following documentation, VBScript's True is equivalent to `-1`. True keyword Also, False is equivalent to 0. False keyword On the other hand, in the C language, true is equivalent to 1 and false is equivalent to 0 in stdbool.h. #ifndef __cplusplus #define bool _Bool #define true 1 #define false 0 #else /* __cplusplus */Also, in JavaScript, if you cast true to an integer type, it will be 1.

item.title: [Python] Install Bash on Ubuntu on Windows, Ruby, Python, Jupyter etc.
item.description: ##background While changing the environment setting of the personal computer, I could not use gnuplot or Ruby’s Narray with Cygwin, so I decided to replace it with bash. I also installed Python and Jupyter. #Bash on Ubuntu on Windows Installation I have referred to this article. Let’s install Bash on Ubuntu on Windows! Go to Settings> Update & Security> For Developers and select Developer Mode. Start the command prompt, type bash and press Enter to start the installation.

item.title: [Python] Summary of multi-process processing of script language
item.description: # Overview The impression that programming and languages that are aware of scalability, such as parallel/parallel processing, functional type, and reactive, have recently attracted attention. Therefore, we summarized the basic writing method of multi-process processing using three script languages often used in Web development. #Environment Language Ruby 2.2 Python 3.1 PHP 5.6 Execution environment Vagrant CentOS6.4 memory 1024MB CPU core 4 config.vm.provider :virtualbox do |vb| vb.

item.title: [Python] How to handle JSON with Ruby, Python, JavaScript, PHP
item.description: I have confirmed how to encode and decode JSON with Python, Ruby, JavaScript, and PHP. For Python #!/usr/bin/env python # -*- coding:utf-8 -*- # import json # Dictionary format data dic1 = {"key1": None, "key2": None} dic1["key1"] = 24 dic1["key2"] = 45 print dic1 # Convert from dictionary format to JSON json_data1 = json.dumps(dic1, sort_keys=True,indent=4) print json_data1 json_data2 = json.dumps(dic1,sort_keys=True) print json_data2 json_data3 = json.dumps(dic1) print json_data3 dic2 = json.
